title: 108_hr4550
content: The Act titled "Safe, Efficient, Coordinated, Unified, Revitalized, Enhanced Visa Waiver Act" allows for electronic submission of biographical information by visa waiver participants. The Secretary of Homeland Security must establish an electronic system for visa waiver program participants to submit biographical information before entering the US. The system must electronically determine eligibility. The Secretary of Homeland Security must establish an electronic system for visa waiver program participants to submit biographical information before entering the US. The system must electronically determine eligibility within 30 minutes for nonimmigrant visitors. The electronic system for visa waiver program participants determines eligibility for nonimmigrant visitors entering the US. Carriers and corporations must inquire electronically about passengers without a visa before embarkation. The system described in section 217(a)(5) of the Act allows for electronic inquiries about the eligibility of alien passengers without a visa before embarkation. The electronic response must be provided within 90 seconds. The system deployment should occur promptly after the enactment of the Act, and a fee will be charged to eligible aliens. The system described in section 217(a)(5) of the Act allows for electronic inquiries about the eligibility of alien passengers without a visa before embarkation. The system shall be deployed promptly after the enactment of this Act, and a fee will be charged to eligible aliens to cover the costs of establishing and operating the system. The Secretary of Homeland Security must consult with a private sector group with expertise in various relevant areas during the system's development. CHANGE TO REQUIREMENT FOR READERS AND SCANNERS AT PORTS OF ENTRY. The Enhanced Border Security and Visa Entry Reform Act requires the installation of biometric equipment and software at all U.S. ports of entry by October 26, 2004 for authentication of visas and travel documents issued to aliens. The Enhanced Border Security and Visa Entry Reform Act mandates the installation of biometric equipment and software at all U.S. ports of entry by October 26, 2005 for biometric comparison and authentication of passports issued to aliens. The Technology Standard Implementation Deadline in the Enhanced Border Security and Visa Entry Reform Act is amended to 2005 from 2004. Additionally, a Limited Good Faith Waiver is introduced. The Enhanced Border Security and Visa Entry Reform Act amends Section 303(c) to allow the Secretary of Homeland Security to grant up to 2 extensions for countries making progress on passport issuance deadlines. The Enhanced Border Security and Visa Entry Reform Act allows the Secretary of Homeland Security to grant extensions for countries making progress on passport issuance deadlines, based on specified factors certified by the Secretary of State. The Secretary of Homeland Security considers factors certified by the Secretary of State to grant extensions for countries progressing on passport issuance deadlines. Factors include good faith efforts by October 26, 2005, a program by October 26, 2006, and initiation of the process. The Secretary of Homeland Security will assess if a country has a program in place by October 26, 2006, and has started a pilot program issuing compliant passports by March 26, 2006. Initial reports are due by October 26, 2005. The Secretary of Homeland Security will issue an initial report on countries' progress by October 26, 2005, and a final report by April 25, 2006, regarding meeting the requirements for compliant passports. The Secretary of Homeland Security, in consultation with the Secretary of State, will issue a final report by April 25, 2006, on countries' progress in meeting passport requirements. SEC. 6. TECHNICAL AND CONFORMING AMENDMENTS. Section 303 of the Enhanced Border Security and Visa Entry Reform Act is amended to replace "Attorney General" with "Secretary of Homeland Security."
